sen.j: 妙心寺（みょうしんじ）は、京都市右京区花園 (京都市)にある臨済宗妙心寺派大本山の寺院。
sen.e: Myoshin-ji Temple is situated in Hanazono, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City and is the head temple of the Rinzai sect Myoshin-ji School of Zen Buddhism.
Myoshin-ji Temple is situated in Hanazono, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City and is the head temple of the Rinzai sect Myoshin-ji School of Zen Buddhism.
Myoshin-ji Temple is situated in Hanazono, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City and is the head temple of the Rinzai sect Myoshin-ji School of Zen Buddhism.

sen.j: 山号を正法山と称する。
sen.e: Its honorific mountain prefix is 'Shobozan'.
Its honorific mountain prefix is 'Shobozan.'
Its honorific mountain prefix is Shobozan.

sen.j: 本尊は釈迦如来、開基（創立者）は花園天皇、開山（初代住職）は関山慧玄（かんざんえげん、無相大師）である。
sen.e: The object of veneration is Shaka Nyorai, the kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding) was Emperor Hanazono and the kaizan (first chief priest) was Kanzan Egen (Muso-daishi).
sen.cmt: ・Shaka Nyorai: http://www.kcn-net.org/e_kama_history/glossary/glossary.htm・kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding): http://www.kcn-net.org/e_kama_history/glossary/glossary.htm・Emperor Hanazono: 英辞郎 on the WEB (-天皇)
sen.e: The object of veneration is Shaka Nyorai, the kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding) was Emperor Hanazono and the kaisan (first chief priest) was Kanzan Egen (Muso-daishi).
sen.cmt: founding)の後のスペースを調整。kaizan→kaisan
sen.e: The object of veneration is Shaka Nyorai, the kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding) was Emperor Hanazono and the kaisan (first chief priest) was Kanzan Egen (Muso-daishi).

sen.j: 日本にある臨済宗寺院約6,000か寺のうち、約3,500か寺を妙心寺派で占める。
sen.e: Of the approximately 6,000 Rinzai sect temples in Japan, around 3,500 belong to the Myoshin-ji School.
Of the approximately 6,000 Rinzai sect temples in Japan, around 3,500 belong to the Myoshin-ji School.
Of the approximately 6,000 Rinzai sect temples in Japan, around 3,500 belong to the Myoshin-ji School.

sen.j: 近世に再建された三門、仏殿、法堂（はっとう）などの中心伽藍の周囲には多くの塔頭寺院（たっちゅうじいん、子院）が建ち並び、一大寺院群を形成している。
sen.e: It is a large temple complex with a central monastery that includes structures such as the recently rebuilt Sammon gate, Butsuden (Buddha hall), Hatto (lecture hall), which is surrounded by numerous sub-temples.

It is a large temple complex with a central monastery that includes structures such as the recently rebuilt Sammon gate, Butsuden (Buddha hall), Hatto (lecture hall), which is surrounded by numerous sub-temples.

It is a large temple complex with a central monastery that includes structures such as the recently rebuilt Sammon gate, Butsuden (Buddha hall), Hatto (lecture hall), which is surrounded by numerous sub-temples.

sen.j: 京都の禅寺は、五山十刹（ござんじっさつ）に代表される、室町幕府の庇護と統制下にあった一派と、それとは一線を画す在野の寺院とがあった。
sen.e: The Zen temples of Kyoto consisted of those under the protection and control of the Muromachi Shogunate as typified Gozan-Jissetsu system institutions and those outside of the system.
sen.cmt: ・Muromachi Shogunate: 英辞郎 on the WEB・Gozan-Jissetsu: http://global.sotozen-net.or.jp/eng/history.html
sen.e: The Zen temples of Kyoto consisted of those under the protection and control of the Muromachi Shogunate as typified Gozan-Jissetsu system institutions and those outside of the system.
The Zen temples of Kyoto consisted of those under the protection and control of the Muromachi Shogunate as typified Gozan-Jissetsu system institutions and those outside of the system.

sen.j: 前者を「禅林」または「叢林」（そうりん）、後者を「林下」（りんか）といった。
sen.e: The former were referred to as 'Zenrin' or 'Sorin', and the latter were referred to as 'Rinka'.
The former were referred to as 'Zenrin' or 'Sorin,' and the latter were referred to as 'Rinka.'
The former were referred to as 'Zenrin' or 'Sorin,' and the latter were referred to as 'Rinka.'

sen.j: 妙心寺は、大徳寺とともに、修行を重んじる厳しい禅風を特色とする「林下」の代表的寺院である。
sen.e: Along with Daitoku-ji Temple, Myoshin-ji Temple is representative of strict Rinka temples that were characterized by an emphasis on training.
Along with Daitoku-ji Temple, Myoshin-ji Temple is representative of strict Rinka temples that were characterized by an emphasis on training.
Along with Daitoku-ji Temple, Myoshin-ji Temple is representative of strict Rinka temples that were characterized by an emphasis on training.

sen.j: 今の妙心寺の地には、花園上皇の離宮・萩原殿があった。
sen.e: Today, the precinct of Myoshin-ji Temple contains the villa of Emperor Hanazono named 'Hagiwaradono'.
sen.cmt: ・Emperor Hanazono: 英辞郎 on the WEB (-天皇)
sen.e: Today, the precinct of Myoshin-ji Temple contains the villa of Emperor Hanazono named 'Hagiwaradono.'
Today, the precinct of Myoshin-ji Temple contains the villa of the Retired Emperor Hanazono named Hagiwaradono.
sen.cmt: 原文に「」のない' 'を削除"Emperor Hanazono"→"the Retired Emperor Hanazono"に変更しました。

sen.j: 花園上皇は、建武 (日本)2年（1335年）落飾（剃髪して仏門に入ること）して法皇となり、萩原殿を禅寺に改めることを発願した。
sen.e: In 1335, the abdicated Emperor Hanazono shaved his head and became a monk, after which he vowed to convert the Hagiwaradono villa into a Zen temple.
In 1335, the abdicated Emperor Hanazono shaved his head and became a monk, after which he vowed to convert the Hagiwaradono villa into a Zen temple.
In 1335, the Rretired Emperor Hanazono shaved his head and became a monk, after which he vowed to convert the Hagiwaradono villa into a Zen temple.

sen.j: 法皇の禅の上での師は大徳寺開山の宗峰妙超（しゅうほうみょうちょう、大燈国師）であった。
sen.e: The emperor-monk's Zen master was Daitoku-ji Temple kaizan Shuho Myocho (Daito-kokushi).
The emperor-monk's Zen master was Daitoku-ji Temple kaisan Shuho Myocho (Daito-kokushi).
The Cloistered Emperor's Zen master was Daitoku-ji Temple kaisan Shuho Myocho (Daito-kokushi).

sen.j: 宗峰は建武4年（1337年）12月没するが、臨終間近の宗峰に花園法皇が「師の亡き後、自分は誰に法を問えばよいか」と尋ねたところ、宗峰は高弟の関山慧玄（かんざんえげん、1277-1360）を推挙した。
sen.e: Shuho passed away in the 12th month of 1337, but, after asking Hanazono on his deathbed who he should pass on his position to, he recommended leading disciple Kanzan Egen (1277-1360).

Shuho passed away in the 12th month of 1337, but, after asking the monk-emperor Hanazono on his deathbed who he should pass on his position to, he recommended leading disciple Kanzan Egen (1277-1360).

Shuho passed away in the 12th month of 1337, but, after asking the Cloistered Emperor Hanazono on his deathbed who he should pass on his position to, he recommended leading disciple Kanzan Egen (1277-1360).

sen.j: その頃、美濃国（岐阜県）の山奥で修行に明け暮れていた関山は、都に戻ることを渋っていたが、師僧・宗峰の遺命と花園法皇の院宣があっては辞去するわけにはいかず、暦応5年/康永元年（1342年）、妙心寺の開山となった。
sen.e: At this time, Kanzan was training in the mountains of Mino Province (Gifu Prefecture) and was reluctant to return to Kyoto, but on receiving the dying instructions of his teacher Shuho and the imperial decree of Hanazono, he could not refuse and assumed the position of kaizan at Myoshin-ji Temple in 1324.
sen.cmt: ・Mino Province: プログレッシブ英和中辞典、http://www.123exp-geography.com/t/18624171939/
sen.e: At this time, Kanzan was training in the mountains of Mino Province (Gifu Prefecture) and was reluctant to return to Kyoto, but on receiving the dying instructions of his teacher Shuho and the imperial decree of Hanazono, he could not refuse and assumed the position of kaisan at Myoshin-ji Temple in 1342.

At this time, Kanzan was training in the mountains of Mino Province (Gifu Prefecture) and was reluctant to return to Kyoto, but on receiving the dying instructions of his teacher Shuho and the imperial decree of Hanazono, he could not refuse and assumed the position of kaisan at Myoshin-ji Temple in 1342.

sen.j: なお、「正法山妙心寺」の山号寺号は宗峰が命名したもので、釈尊が嗣法の弟子・摩訶迦葉（まかかしょう）に向かって述べた「正法眼蔵涅槃妙心」（「最高の悟り」というほどの意味）という句から取ったものである。
sen.e: The full title of 'Shobozan Myoshin-ji Temple' was given by Shuho and Shaka

The temple's full title 'Shobozan Myoshin-ji' was given by Shuho and derived from the words 'Shoho ganzo nehan myoshin' (approximately meaning 'ultimate enlightenment') spoken by Shaka to his disciple Mahakasyapa.
sen.cmt: 後方の ' が抜けている為補足。
sen.e: The temple's full title 'Shobozan Myoshin-ji' was given by Shuho and derived from the words 'Shoho ganzo nehan myoshin' (approximately meaning 'ultimate enlightenment') spoken by Shaka to his disciple Mahakasyapa.

sen.j: 関山慧玄の禅風は厳格で、その生活は質素をきわめたという。
sen.e: Kanzan's style of Zen Buddhism was strict and he lived his life to the utmost level of simplicity.
Kanzan Egen's style of Zen Buddhism was strict and he lived his life to the utmost level of simplicity.
Kanzan Egen's style of Zen Buddhism was strict and he lived his life to the utmost level of simplicity.

sen.j: 関山には他の高僧のような「語録」はなく、生前に描かれた肖像もなく、遺筆も弟子の授翁宗弼（じゅおうそうひつ）に書き与えた印可状（師匠の法を受け継いだ証明書）のほかほとんど残されていない。
sen.e: Unlike other eminent monks, there are no analects left by Kanzan, no portraits painted during his lifetime and the only example of his writing is the inka (master's certification of a disciple's completion of training) that he presented to his disciple Juo Sohitsu.

Unlike other eminent monks, there are no analects left by Kanzan, no portraits painted during his lifetime and the only example of his writing is the inka (master's certification of a disciple's completion of training) that he presented to his disciple Juo Sohitsu.

Unlike other eminent monks, there are no analects left by Kanzan, no portraits painted during his lifetime and the only example of his writing is the inka (master's certification of a disciple's completion of training) that he presented to his disciple Juo Sohitsu.

sen.j: 妙心寺6世住持の拙堂宗朴（せつどうそうぼく）は、足利氏に反旗をひるがえした大内義弘と関係が深かったため、将軍足利義満の怒りを買った。
sen.e: Shogun Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA was enraged when Setsudo Soboku, the 6th chief priest of Myoshin-ji Temple, flew the flag of revolt against the Ashikaga Clan.

Shogun Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA was enraged because Setsudo Soboku, the 6th chief priest of Myoshin-ji Temple, had a close relationship with Yoshihiro OUCHI who flew the flag of revolt against the Ashikaga Clan.
sen.cmt: 原文の、"大内義弘と関係が深かったため"部分を補足。when→becausehad a close relationship with Yoshihiro OUCHI whoを追加。
sen.e: Shogun Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA was enraged because Setsudo Soboku, the 6th chief priest of Myoshin-ji Temple, had a close relationship with Yoshihiro OUCHI who flew the flag of revolt against the Ashikaga Clan.

sen.j: 応永6年（1399年）、義満は妙心寺の寺領を没収し、拙堂宗朴は大内義弘に連座して青蓮院に幽閉の身となった。
sen.e: In 1399, Yoshimitsu confiscated Myoshin-ji Temple, implicated Setsudo Soboku as being involved with Yoshihiro OUCHI and had him confined to Shoren-in Temple.
In 1399, Yoshimitsu confiscated Myoshin-ji Temple, implicated Setsudo Soboku as being involved with Yoshihiro OUCHI and had him confined to Shoren-in Temple.
In 1399, Yoshimitsu confiscated Myoshin-ji Temple, implicated Setsudo Soboku as being involved with Yoshihiro OUCHI and had him confined to Shoren-in Temple.

sen.j: 妙心寺は応仁の乱（1467-1477年）で伽藍を焼失したが、中興の祖である雪江宗深（せっこうそうしん、1408-1486）の尽力により復興。
sen.e: The monastery at Myoshin-ji Temple was destroyed by fire during the Onin War (1467-1477) but was reconstructed thanks to the efforts of the Sekko Soshi.
The monastery at Myoshin-ji Temple was destroyed by fire during the Onin War (1467-1477) but was reconstructed thanks to the efforts of the Sekko Soshi (1408-1486).
The monastery at Myoshin-ji Temple was destroyed by fire during the Onin War (1467-1477) but was reconstructed thanks to the efforts of the Sekko Soshi (1408-1486).

sen.j: 細川家や豊臣家などの有力者の援護を得て、近世には大いに栄えた。
sen.e: The temple has received the backing of influential individuals including those from the Hosokawa and Toyotomi families and continued to flourish into modern times.
The temple has received the backing of influential individuals including those from the Hosokawa and Toyotomi families and continued to flourish into modern times.
The temple has received the backing of influential individuals including those from the Hosokawa and Toyotomi families and continued to flourish into modern times.

sen.j: 勅使門-慶長15年（1610年）建立。
sen.e: Chokushi-mon gate (gate for imperial envoys) - Built in 1610.
sen.cmt: ・Chokushi-mon gate (the Gate for the Imperial Envoys): http://p-www.iwate-pu.ac.jp/~acro-ito/Japan_pics/Japan_KYE/imageidx.html
sen.e: Chokushi-mon Gate (gate for the imperial envoys) - Built in 1610.
Chokushi-mon Gate (gate for the imperial envoys) - Built in 1610.

sen.j: 三門-慶長4年（1599年）建立。
sen.e: Sanmon gate - Built in 1599.
Sammon Gate - Built in 1599.
Sammon Gate - Built in 1599.

sen.j: 五間三戸（正面の柱間5間のうち中央3間が通路）の二重門（2階建門）である。
sen.e: A two-storey gate with five bays and three entrances (three of the five front bays are entrances).
A two-storey gate with five bays and three entrances (three of the five front bays are entrances).
A two-storey gate with five bays and three entrances (three of the five front bays are entrances).

sen.j: 上層には円通大士（観音）と十六羅漢像を安置する。
sen.e: The upper storey houses statues of Enzu-Daishi (Kannon) and the 16 arhats.
sen.cmt: ・Enzu-Daishi (Kannon): プログレッシブ和英辞典
sen.e: The upper storey houses statues of Enzu-Daishi (Kannon) and Juroku-Rakan-zo (the 16 arhats).
The upper storey houses statues of Enzu-Daishi (Kannon) and Juroku-Rakan-zo (the 16 arhats).

sen.j: 仏殿-他の諸堂より新しく、文政10年（1827年）の建立。
sen.e: Butsuden (Buddha hall) - Newer than the other halls, having been built in 1827.
Butsuden (Buddha hall) - Newer than the other halls, having been built in 1827.
Butsuden (Buddha hall) - Newer than the other halls, having been built in 1827.

sen.j: 入母屋造、一重裳階（もこし）付き。
sen.e: Features a hip-and-gable roof.
Features a single pent hip-and-gable roof.
sen.cmt: 裳階→pent roof※一重は"一階建て"という意味。
sen.e: Features a single pent hip-and-gable roof.

sen.j: 法堂（はっとう）-明暦2年（1656年）の建立。
sen.e: Hatto (lecture hall) - Built in 1656.

sen.j: 入母屋造、一重裳階付き。

sen.j: 大方丈-承応3年（1654年）の建立。
sen.e: O-hojo (large Abbot's quarters) - Built in 1654.
O-hojo (large Abbot's quarters) - Built in 1654.
O-hojo (large Abbot's quarters) - Built in 1654.

sen.j: 障壁画は南側3室は狩野探幽、北側3室は狩野洞雲の筆。
sen.e: The partition paintings in the three south rooms are by Tan'yu KANO and those in the three north rooms are by Toun KANO.
The partition paintings in the three south rooms are by Tan'yu KANO and those in the three north rooms are by Toun KANO.

sen.j: 庫裏-承応2年（1653年）の建立。
sen.e: Kuri (priest's living quarters or kitchen) - Built in 1653.
Kuri (priest's living quarters or kitchen) - Built in 1653.

sen.j: 他に小方丈、浴室、経蔵などがある（以上の建造物はすべて重要文化財）。

sen.j: 妙心寺の塔頭は48箇院に及び、うち山内塔頭38箇院、境外塔頭は石庭で著名な龍安寺を含め10箇院を数える。
sen.e: Myoshin-ji Temple has a total of 48 sub-temples which includes 38 within the precinct itself and 10 outside of the temple grounds, of which Ryoan-ji Temple, renowned for its rock garden, is one.

sen.j: 梵鐘-戊戌（つちのえいぬ）年、つまり西暦698年にあたる年の銘文がある、日本最古の紀年銘鐘。
sen.e: Temple bell - This is Japan's oldest bell inscribed with the ancient lunar calendar year corresponding to the Gregorian calendar year 698.
Temple bell - This is Japan's oldest bell inscribed with the ancient lunar calendar year corresponding to the Gregorian calendar year 698.
Temple bell - This is Japan's oldest bell inscribed with the ancient lunar calendar year corresponding to the Gregorian calendar year 698.

sen.j: 九州方面で制作されたものである。
sen.e: It was cast in the Kyushu region.
It was cast in the Kyushu region.
It was cast in the Kyushu region.

sen.j: 妙心寺には2個所（法堂の北西と仏殿の南東）あるが、前者の鐘楼にかかっていたもの（現在は法堂に移動）。
sen.e: Myoshin-ji Temple has two bells (northwest of the hatto and southeast of the butsuden), but this one was housed within the former bell tower (now moved to the hatto).
Myoshin-ji Temple has two bells (northwest of the Hatto and southeast of the Butsuden), but this one was housed within the former bell tower (now moved to the Hatto).
Myoshin-ji Temple has two bells (northwest of the Hatto and southeast of the Butsuden), but this one was housed within the former bell tower (now moved to the Hatto).

sen.j: 音色が雅楽の黄鐘調（おうじきちょう）に合うことから古来「黄鐘調の鐘」として著名で、『徒然草』にもこの鐘のことが言及されている。
sen.e: The bell sound matches that of a garaku scale named 'oshikicho' so has long been known as 'Oshikicho Bell' and is referred to in 'Tsurezuregusa' (Essays in Idleness).
The bell sound matches that of a garaku scale named 'ojikicho' so has long been known as 'Ojikicho Bell' and is referred to in "Tsurezuregusa" (Essays in Idleness).
sen.cmt: おうじきちょう、なので→ojikicho『』→ ""
sen.e: The bell sound matches that of a garaku scale named ojikicho so has long been known as 'Ojikicho Bell' and is referred to in "Tsurezuregusa" (Essays in Idleness).

sen.j: 大燈国師墨蹟-宗峰妙超（大燈国師）が弟子の関山慧玄（妙心寺開山）に「関山」の号を与えたときに書き与えたもの。
sen.e: Writing of Daito-kokushi - Written by Shuho Myocho (Daito-kokushi) to his student Kanzan Egen (Myosjin-ji kaizan) when he conferred upon him the name 'Kanzan'.
Writing of Daito-kokushi - Written by Shuho Myocho (Daito-kokushi) to his student Kanzan Egen (Myosjin-ji kaisan) when he conferred upon him the name 'Kanzan'.
Writing of Daito-kokushi - Written by Shuho Myocho (Daito-kokushi) to his student Kanzan Egen (Myoshin-ji kaisan) when he conferred upon him the name 'Kanzan.'

sen.j: 大燈国師墨蹟-宗峰妙超が関山慧玄に与えた「印可状」（自分の法を継いだというお墨付き）である。
sen.e: Writing of Daito-kokushi - The inka (master's certification of a disciple's completion of training) given by Shuho Myocho to his disciple Kanzan Egen.
